text: No cars. Swirls of newspapers blow across the street. Suddenly, a YELLOW SCHOOL BUS BECOMES VISIBLE, rising ove hill. As it gets nearer, we feel the ROAR of the engine. The bus is a monster. As it rumbles by us we SEE "SUNNY MEADOWS HIGH SCHOOL" inscribed on the side.

Grimy. Run down. School Bus Hell. Oppressed grey-faced HIGH SCHOOLERS sit round-shouldered, looking out into now land. WE DOLLY SLOWLY ALONG the floor TO REVEAL all the student ankles SHACKLED and CHAINED to their seats. The faint rhy of a FILE RUBBING AGAINST STEEL becomes louder and louder until the CAMERA STOPS ON a student's hands. Seconds away from filing through the lock on his shackle... FREEDOM. The CAMERA TILTS UP TO REVEAL LES ANDERSON, sixteen, mayb seventeen. He's the only kid on the bus with a spark of l left in him. As the bus stops at a RED LIGHT, something catches Les' e

He wipes the window, revealing a RED FERRARI 308 GIB park beside the bus, outside a CORNER GROCERY STORE. The T-ROO is off, and all we CAN SEE are the LONGEST, MOST BEAUTIFU LEGS lounging in the passenger seat. A GUY walks away fro the car into the store.
lecks to the back of the bus, to the REAR DOOR, clearly marked "FOR EMERGENCY USE ONLY." He teeters on the edge o his seat, about to make a move. He looks to the front of bus, at the:

A maniac: mid-40s, lousy toupee. He's been watching Les i his rearview mirror the entire time. They stare at each other, eye to eye. Les holds his ground. The driver thrus the bus in gear and begins to pull away... away from the Ferrari. (CONTINUED )

Les explodes from his seat, charging for the "emergency door." The kids come to life, watching and screaming with excitement. Les kicks at the door. A RED WARNING LIGHT on the Driver's dash flashes. An ALAR sounds. The Driver looks back, angrily. Then pushes a button. A STEEL BOLT slams across the door. Les slams through the back window -- diving out of the bus onto the street. Les bounces out of a COMMANDO ROLL and runs up the street to Ferrari. The bus does a spectacular BOOTLEGGER'S turn. It's coming back.

Keys dangle from the ignition. In the passenger seat is t LEGGIEST BLONDE GIRL you've ever seen. The approaching bu builds speed. Les jumps into the car. She smiles, seductively. He smiles back. They're in love. The bus screams towards them. Les turns the ignition, pop the clutch, then squeals into a right turn slicing onto a
The bus roars after them, barely making the turn, balanci on two wheels.

Looks at his speedometer: 70... 75... 80... 85. Maple tre whip by like he's in a rocket ship. AWESOME! He looks up his rearview mirror. It's all yellow. Miraculously, the b is right on his tail. Suddenly:

Hops the curb and bicycles across the street. Les, about hit him, yanks the wheel left, practically tearing it off column. The bus bombs by, slicing the front tire off the bike. The LITTLE BOY is left there on his seat, spinning around acrobatically on his back tire.
still trying to lose the bus, streaks down a street, then screeches into: (CONTINUED )

So narrow they spell it with one "1". The bus slams in, rocking and rebounding off the alley's walls. Dragging po cords and live wires, sparks shoot out from the bus' side Les jams on his brakes, cuts and slides right onto a:

Les guns it! A laser beam. With one hand he downshifts to accelerate, with the other, he starts to light the girl's cigarette... She pulls his hand closer to her, looking in his eyes. But WAIT! Up ahead, by a GAS STATION, there's a HUGE PUDD OF WATER. But it's not water. It's GAS! A tank pumps gas into a tanker fuel truck. GAS spews from a ruptured hose. Suddenly, we hear a BORING MONOTONE voice.
Remember. Be prepared and look ahead. The driver must see the BIG PICTURE...

A dark classroom. The sound of a projector. Flickering light. An instructional film is being shown to a class of DRIVER'S ED STUDENTS. The CAMERA MOVES THROUGH the room a stops in back where we FIND Les Anderson, head on his des fast asleep, resting on his DRIVER'S ED BOOKS.
«+eIn heavier rain, your tires may begin to 'hydroplane,' ride on the water, rather than the pavement. Don't panic! And especially don't jam on the brakes. Ease your foot off the gas pedal.

High speed. There's no avoiding the puddle. Les EASES HIS FOOT off the gas pedal. The Ferrari remains steady as a 1 foot spray of gas erupts on either side of the car. He finishes lighting the girl's cigarette, then casually tos the match out the window. (CONTINUED )
The driver shifts gears with reckless abandon, charging f the puddle. Suddenly, the puddle ignites. There's a HUGE EXPLOSION. The bus driver JAMMMMS on his brakes. Headed straight for it.

Les and the girl hear the explosion and turn around simultaneously. There's no bus, just a huge WALL OF FLAME They smile at each other. They've made it... Les leans ov to kiss her, but suddenly she's not smiling. Her mouth is open in shock. There's terror in her eyes. We hear the RO OF AN ENGINE. Les looks back at the road.

head_text.subj: THE BUS IS HEADED STRAIGHT FOR THEM

text: about to smash into them. WE HEAR a LOUD HORN which becom a SCHOOL BELL.

He wakes up, startled. He has sleep marks on one side of face. He looks around, embarrassed. The bell stops. Standing in front of him is the DRIVER'S ED TEACHER, MR. GASKET, the bus driver from the dream. The class is getti up from their desks, leaving. He motions for Les not to move. Leaving the class, A VERY CUTE GIRL turns to Les' twin sister, NATALIE -- she's conservative, bookish.
(low voice) Does your brother have mono or something? He slept through the entire course.
No, he's just brain dead. The class empties. Mr. Gasket stands ominously above Les.
(dead serious) Mr. Anderson. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

MR. GASKET (cont'd) It's punks like you the paramedics end up scraping off the roads at four in the morning. (beat) For your own sake and the safety of others, I hope you fail your driver's exam. Les gets up to leave. Gasket signals to stay, then throws him a piece of chalk. Les rolls his eyes.
Kids load into YELLOW SCHOOL BUSES and fancy cars.
LINES. Blackboards full of "I WILL DRIVE SAFELY. I WILL DRIVE SAFELY..." Les finishes his last one and flies out class.
Buses and cars begin to pull away.
Deserted. Sprinting. Les slides to his locker and quickly unlocks it. An avalanche of books and junk fall onto the floor. He stuffs it back in.

A few kids here and there. Les bombs out of school, jammi papers into his knapsack. He runs down the street after t last departing school bus. He can't catch it. Natalie, inside the bus, smiles at him. He stands in the middle of the road, pissed. We hear a car racing towards him from behind.

The one from the dream. T-roof off. Music blares. MERCEDE LANE, the leggy blonde girl from the dream, sits in the passenger seat. PAOLO, her GQ Latin American boyfriend, drives. They're in their own perfect world. (CONTINUED )

Les jumps out of the way as it screams by him. He watches the Ferrari drive off. We hear a bicycle tire SKIDDING along the pavement. He tu to see: A "nut case" on a ten speed stop his thirty foot skid a h away from Les' sneaker. This is DEAN, Les' best friend. H has charm and mischief with a capital M written all over face. They both look back at the Ferrari.
You know, Dean, I can't help wondering whether it'll ever get that good for me.

Anderson, the only difference between you and that greaseball, is that he has a license and you don't. In two days we open a whole new chapter. (motioning to his handle bars) Get in. I'll drive you home. Les looks at Dean's BEAT TO SHIT death trap bike.
Unh, unh. Too much is at stake. They'll never let me take my driver's exam in traction.
Les, your license is as important to me as it is to you. I'll take it easy. I promise.
White knuckles. Les hangs on as a sadistic Dean speeds al the sidewalk. About to collide with a JOGGER, Dean cuts onto:
zigzagging in and out of TRAFFIC. A HONK here, a honk the Dean JOLTS the bike back up on the SIDEWALK. (CONTINUED )
Les tries to absorb the shock. Dean laughs, pedals faster He whips Les through:
They flap against Les' face. Dean's having a riot. Les wants to start one. The torturous branches give way to:

head_text.subj: A FEROCIOUS DOG CHAINED ON A PORCH

text: Dean has the bike headed straight for it. Its mouth salivates. As Dean swerves Les by it, the dog runs and pu his chain taut, swinging out against an imaginary wall.

making sure to run Les through a SPRINKLER. This is Les' house; large and colonial, its landscaping perfectly groo Ahead of them, in front of the garage, there's an Audi 50 Turbo. It's surrounded by mounds of dusty boxes and garag junk. Dean slaloms through it.

sits parked at an angle, barely squeezing in. Sky blue. Gleaming chrome. It's in mint condition. Dean and Les rid in. Dean jams on the brakes. Les slides painfully off the handlebars. He gives Dean a dirty look. END OF CREDITS.
Just a painful reminder of what you're leaving behind. (beat) Whose Caddie?
My grandfather's. Can you believe it's sixteen years old? It only has twenty thousand miles on it. Dean gets off his bike and lets it crash to the ground.
(examining it) It's intense. What's it doing here? (CONTINUED )
He's afraid to take it on long trips so he borrowed my dad's car for a week.
(opening the door) I gotta tell you, Les, this boat would kick-ass up at Archie’s. Do you think we can get it for Saturday night?
(o.s8.) Not a chance in hell, Dean. They turn. It's Les' DAD -- good-looking, early forties, wears grimy work clothes. He walks into the garage, remov Dean's hand from the door, and buffs the chrome.
You have a better chance of winning the Nobel Prize for physics than you do of getting in this car. Les looks at Dean as if to say "Does that answer your question?"
Hi Dad.
(to the boys) How ‘bout a hand helping me move this junk?
(picking up his bike) I'd really love to, Mr. Anderson, (a fake cough) but I'm sort of allergic to dust and cardboard boxes. He coughs again. Dad doesn't even bother. Dean gets on hi bike.
(driving off) See you tonight. (CONTINUED )
Dad? Do you think you could tell me for sure if I can use Mom's car Saturday night?
(shoving a dusty box at him) Do me a favor, will ya, Les? Just pass your driver's exam. And then we'll talk.
Dad, Les, Natalie and Rudy sit at the table. Rudy is the cute, ten year old brother you can only find in the movie As they munch away at their dinner, one by one they look in awe...

Looking more like nine years pregnant, rather than nine months, she carries the most humongous plate of mashed potatoes, spotted with mini-pickles, chocolate chips and potato chips. Instead of putting it in the center of the table, she plops it down in front of her table setting. With the family still looking on disgustedly, she picks u the ketchup bottle, and starts squirting it out on her fo (HAPPY FACE)...
For your information, this is exactly what I ate when I was pregnant with all of you. She downs her first bite. It scares them back to their meals.
Dad?
Unh, unh.
Did you get a chance to look at those brochures? (CONTINUED )
(pulling a crumpled brochure from his back pocket) Sure did.
Well? What do you think?
(flipping through it) A twenty-three thousand dollar BMW for a sixteen year old kid who's never had a job in his life? I think it's a great idea. Les is humiliated.
Les, you only completed your driver's ed course two hours ago. You don't even have a license yet.
But Dad, it wouldn't be just for me. It would be for Natalie too.
Don't include me in your obsession.
Excuse me, Miss Mature. Is there anything wrong with being American?
A BMW at sixteen? It's more like spoiled. Karl says... Everyone stops what they're doing ala E. F. Hutton.

Can you people please be serious for once in your life? (beat) Karl says that in America the people are misled to believe that a car represents freedom and individuality, when, in essence, it is more oppressive than anything else, burdening the individual with materialistic costs, such as insurance, gas and repairs. (CONTINUED )
Who cares what your Commie boyfriend thinks? I think we'd all prefer to be burdened with the cost of an automobile, than with bread lines and two year waiting lists for a washing machine.
I agree. Mother starts to boil.
You two are so simple, it's frightening.
Why are you even getting your license?
(upset and getting up from the table) I'm not hungry.
Natalie, if you prefer to eat standing up, that's fine with me. But nobody leaves the table until we finish eating.
This is the most oppressive environment a child could be subjected to. Natalie sits down. We hear a loud HONK-HONK! Les stands u
(wiping his mouth) That's for me.
You heard me Les. Whoever it is will have to wait a few minutes.
(still standing) But, Maaa. (CONTINUED )

Les? Do you want to use my car Saturday night? Les sits down like he's playing musical chairs! The famil eats in silence. We hear another HONK, and then a couple quick HONKS, and then a HONNNKKK... The family tries to ignore it, but it's more than annoying. It starts again:
Hanging over, from the back to the front seat, leaning on horn is Dean. Dean's MOM and his LITTLE SISTER ride in front. They're used to this behavior.
The obnoxious HONKING continues. Everyone except Les has stopped eating. Cheery, he munches away as if nothing is going on. Mom and Dad boil. Dad has had it.
Les, if you're not out of this house in five seconds, there's a good chance you'll never drive anything but a golf ball. A victorious Les calmly excuses himself from the table.

Now this is a party. Loud music. Sixteen-year-old kids al over the place. ALL THE GORGEOUS GIRLS AND GUYS huddle around expensive SLICK DRIVING MACHINES, and competing ca stereos. If you happen to be a male without a car, you ma as well be at home with a Playboy. The Datsun makes its way down the street.

An uncomfortable backseat, filled with junk. Les and Dean sit squished together, practically eating their knees. Th front seat is pushed all the way back. Dean's little munchkin sister sits comfortably in the passenger seat. They approach the party. Dean's mom slows down. Embarrass Dean and Les duck. (CONTINUED )
Is there something wrong with the car, Dean?
It's not the car, Ma. It's you, you're driving. Just drop us off around the corner.

As Dean and Les pull themselves out of the car, a GLOSSY BLACK GTO, with a confederate flag attached to its antenn slows down across the street. Inside the GTO are THREE of the scariest and rowdiest looking HIGH SCHOOL DROPOUTS yo ever seen. They're laughing at the boys being dropped off mom.

Hey boys, does Mommy drive you to the little boys' room, also? Les and Dean are crushed. As the derelicts drive away laughing, we hear their crazy horn. The Funeral March... "DUM, DUM, DaDUM... DUM, DaDUM, DaDUM, DaDUM."
(to his mother) Sorry, I didn't introduce you, Ma. She laughs.
See you at twelve?
I'll be right here at eleven.
I'll call.

It's a school night, Dean. If you're not standing here between eleven and eleven o' two, I'm changing the locks. The Datsun drives off. Composed, they strut around the corner. Ahead of them, in front of the estate and all the kids, a HONDA pulls up. (CONTINUED )

jumps out and WAVES GOOD-BYE TO HIS MOTHER. Older looking but by no means better looking than Les and Dean, he wear glasses and isn't ashamed of being dropped off by his mot He waves to Dean and Les. They turn into the party, ignor him.
Les, Dean, and Charles sip fruit punch. They sit alone on the front steps gawking at the hoards of cute girls surrounding the guys and their cars. Impressive, but sickening.

I know exactly what you're thinking, Les. I'm thinking the same thing. I'm not sure about Charles. (beat) Why am I so alone here? I'm good looking, I've got a great sense of humor, and yet there's not one single female within twenty yards of me? Can you find one of them who isn't within arms reach of a car?
They've even monopolized the fifteen year olds.
You guys are pathetic. Life does exist outside a V-Eight.
Not in this country, it doesn't.

And do you know what the beauty of it all is? The beauty of it all, Les, is that Saturday afternoon, less than forty-eight hours away, the people at the DMV are going to be handing you your license... our Les' eyes glitter. He's in a trance. (CONTINUED )

You can say good-bye to the humiliation of public transportation, and not being able to date someone who isn't conveniently close to a bus stop. You're going to be free, Les. One of them. (beat) And on Saturday night, when we pull into Archie's Atomic in your mom's Audi 5000 TURBO, all this is going to be at our fingertips. In fact, Archie's makes this place look like Sesame Street.
To you Archie's makes the Playboy Channel look like Sesame Street.

Archie's is the joint. I swear it. My brother used to go there every weekend. He says the ratio of girls to guys is five to one. And we're not talkin' dogs, we're talkin' bunnies. The place is a paradise. (beat) I'm telling you, Les. The secret to your happiness, and ultimately our happiness, as long as we live in this country, is a driver's license.
You can't possibly believe that bullshit, can you?
(leoking around at all the cars, girls and happiness) Charles. Seeing is believing. You gotta believe him.  16.
Soft lighting. Kids sitting, standing, talking, necking. Les, Dean, and Charles slump by the punch bowl observing decadence.
Do you ever wonder what kind of car would be most appropriate for some of these wenches to lose their virginity in?
You never cease to amaze me, Deano.
Seriously. Look at Cheryl Lieberman.
A sixteen-year-old JAP. They laugh.
A Camaro.
Cheryl Lieberman? A Trans Am.
Beth Maclaine.
Pristine. Conservative Anglo Saxon.
A Volvo. Maybe a station wagon.
Bonnie Dupa.
We CAN ONLY SEE her face as someone is sitting in front o her. She's sleaze to the max.
(o.8.) A van. (CONTINUED )
(o.s.) Nah, a Harley.
(o.8.; reverent tone) Mercedes.
(0.8.3; shocked) A Mercedes?
They turn to Les only to see him gaping, mouth open. Dean and Charles look up and become entranced, as well.
Standing, framed, in the doorway, backlit, the light shin through her dress, exposing the silhouette of her long le At seventeen she looks twenty. She's an untouchable.
(still reverent) Mercedes Lane.
What more can be said?
I've bumped into her a million times, and she's never once bumped into me. Mercedes heads for them, arguing with her older looking boyfriend, PAOLO. He looks very out of place.

You don't own me, I can do whatever I like. Women have rights in this country. Not like Chile or Argentina, where they worship their men. They barge through the boys as if they were a string of beads. Les "quivers" beside Mercedes as she pours herself some punch. (CONTINUED )
It has nothing to do with worship, it has to do with going to parties with... with kids.
I happen to go to school with these kids. I have friends here.
Friends? These children can do nothing for you.
(cold) Can we just stop this discussion? There are some things you and I will never agree on.
(flustered) Mercedes. I'm beginning to perspire. You know I hate to perspire. (turning to go) Are you coming?
I think I can find my own way home, thank you. He walks away.
And Paolo? If you're wondering about Saturday night, I just remembered...
(turning back) Don't do this to me, Mercedes. You'll regret it.
I've made other plans. I already have a date.
With who?
With him. (CONTINUED )
Mercedes turns to a shocked Les.
Him?
(to Les) Didn't we make arrangements?
(hesitant) I... I believe so. But, nothing was final.
Well now they're final.
You'll pay for this, Mercedes. Paolo storms away. Les watches, afraid to speak. Mercedes downs her punch. She fills her glass again, and downs it. Les who? WE PUSH IN ON Les. He's in a daze.
Kids pile out of class.
Dean and Charles get on the bus. Les stands on the curb. The bus starts its engine. Fancy cars pull away.
I cannot believe you, Les. You're blowing the greatest night of your life for a girl who probably doesn't even know you have a pulse.
Dean, believe it!
(betrayed) That's pathetic. After all these years we finally get a chance to go to Archie's, and now you're telling me it's off? (CONTINUED )
If Mercedes pulls through, you bet.
Why don't you just ask her, to make sure?
I'd love to Charles, but I can't talk to something I can't see. Last night was the closest any of us have ever been to her.

Well you're in luck, loverboy, ‘cause she's sittin' down right behind you. Dean backs away. The bus doors slam closed in Les' face. turns around: Mercedes sits on a bench about twenty-five feet away, rea an ELLE magazine, sipping some apple juice. Les turns back to the bus. It's pulling away.

(leaning out) Go on, ask her. If you're lucky, she'll bite. Les turns back to Mercedes. She's more beautiful than ever. He walks towards her. Her blonde hair flutters in the wind. He stands beside her. Some apple juice dribbles off her bottom lip. She tongues her lips dry. It's the sexiest thing he's ever seen. He can't even talk. She glances up. Not recognizing him, she goes back to her Magazine. We hear a LOUD HONK! HONK! !!!! It scares Mercedes. Les turns, shocked to see his father in the Cadillac, pul up in front of them. He HONKS again. It's the loudest hor in the world. Les, embarrassed, ignores his father.
(rolling down the window) Les? (CONTINUED )
The height of embarrassment. Les coolly walks by Mercedes Then, instead of getting into the car, he walks in front it, across the street. Dad rolls down the window, HONKING again.
Les. It's me, your father. Cringe. He tries to get out of her sight. Mercedes doesn' even notice. Dad follows beside him, like the secret service.
What's going on, here, Les? Don't you recognize me? Still no answer. He turns the corner. So does Dad. Finally, out of her sight, Les gets in.
A WHITE INTERIOR, impeccably clean. The immensity of the dwarfs Les. We SEE BAGS OF PAMPERS in the back seat.
Is there something wrong with having a father, these days?
Dad, what are you doing here?
I ran some errands for your mom, and I thought I'd come by and take you driving. I figured if you could handle this cruiser you could handle anything.
But what about Grandpa?
Don't worry about Grandpa. Who knows what he's doing with my car?
(excited) Okay. Dad slides over. Les climbs into the driver's seat, movin it way up close. (CONTINUED )

He checks his mirrors then takes a deep breath. He puts h flicker on, then pulls out, very slowly... cautiously. Immediately, the car screeches to a halt fifteen feet bef a stop sign. Dad rubs his neck.
Sorry. The brakes are a little sensitive.
Les smoothly turns the Cadillac off a busy street into a residential neighborhood.
Les, driving for a while now, begins to get the hang of i He stops smoothly at a stop sign. Suddenly, he stares wid eyed, frozen.
That's a long enough stop. Make a right here.
I can't.
What's the matter? Up the block, Les sees Mercedes Lane.
I have to ask you a favor. You can say no, but I'll never ask you another one as long as I live.
Les, you know that's a lie.
You see that girl up ahead? Her name is Mercedes Lane. To put it simply, if she asked me to marry her tomorrow, I'd definitely say yes. (CONTINUED )
(excited) So. Let's drive by her.
Dad, she just asked me out last night. If I drive by with you in the car, she'll never look at me again. Even if I were standing on her chest.
You're asking me to let you drive this car, alone? Without a license? Are you insane?
I'll just drive by, say hello and circle back. It'll take two minutes. Dad, sizing up the situation, looks at Les, then at Merce who walks farther up the block.
(earnestly) I just want to see if she was serious.
(with a big heart) Sure.
And Dad... (looking at groceries) Would you mind? What can Dad say? He gets out, with the Pampers, then watches Les pull away.
He rolls down the window and honks. She turns, gives hima dirty look, and keeps walking. He shadows her.
Mercedes? She stops and looks inside, puzzled. (CONTINUED )
Les Anderson, from the party last night.
Oh, you scared me. I didn't recognize you. Some jerk honked at me a little while ago in a car just like this.
You live around here, don't you?
Unh, unh. Just up the street.
Hop in, I'll give you a lift?
Sure, that'd be fun. As she's about to open the front door:
Wait a second. Les jumps out of the car, runs around the passenger side, insists she get in the back seat. Charmed, she does.
down the road, shakes his head in disbelief.
Adjusting the rearview mirror, Les momentarily holds on h chest, then up to her face. He smiles. He sees Dad, in th mirror, holding the bags.
Which house is yours?
It's right down the block. He drives up half a block. (CONTINUED )
(about to pull into the driveway) Okaaayyy-
But... I'm not going home.
(stunned) Where are you going?
Into Cedarbrook, to a friend's place. You don't mind, do you? Les is stunned, caught completely off guard. He looks at his:
His father, still holding the bags, stands alone.
(weakly) No, not at all.
Dad, with the bags beside him on the sidewalk, is livid.
Mercedes walks away from the Cadillac.
(calling out) Mercedes?
(coming back) Unh, unh. (CONTINUED )
(courageous) Last night at the party, you mentioned something about you and I going out Saturday night. I was just curious... Are we still on? She doesn't have the heart.
Sure... Call me, tomorrow.
(pulling out a pen) Great, let me give you my number in case something comes up. You never know.
(handing him her Elle Magazine) Here, write it on this. He excitedly writes his number on the front cover, then h it back to her.
Thanks again for the lift, Les.
No problem.

Les coasts down the street like a cop on surveillance. Suddenly, he spots Dad a block ahead, carrying the huge grocery bags. His jacket is off and his shirt is soaked i sweat. As Les pulls up, Dad glares at him. If looks could kill.
Les sits stiffly, in a chair. Dad disheveled, his shirt soaked with sweat, circles Les like a shark.
(angry) How could you do it, Les? (MORE ) (CONTINUED )
DAD (cont'd) You gave me your word and you used up your last favor? Do you realize where this leaves you?

Not in good shape, but just let me explain. I admit I should never have let her in the car, but she lived three houses down. I thought I was taking her home. (leoking at Mom) Mom, I'm sure there were many similar romantic gestures when Dad was dating you. Mom lies on her side in the den wearing a workout outfit, doing scissor-kick exercises, to a pregnancy video. If Mo Dick were a pregnant woman living in America, she'd look this.
(thinking) I don't know. There must have been. We're married. Mom smiles. Dad looks at her as if to say, "Thanks a lot.
Why didn't you just tell her the truth?

Tell Mercedes Lane I don't have a license? And risk her having a heart attack from laughing so hard? Put yourself in my shoes. Dad looks at Les. Then to Mom for help. Forget it, Dad, you're on your own.
(giving in) Well, consider yourself lucky that I didn't have a heart attack walking home.

Stereo, TV, CD, boyhood Americana. Posters of cars cover walls. We faintly hear classical music seeping through th walls. The boys are over. While Les cuts Mercedes' pictur out of the high school yearbook, Dean gives him a hard ti (CONTINUED )
Do you know what happens if you get caught driving without a license? They make you wait two years before you can take the test again. Two years, Les. Twenty-four months. That's a lot of bus rides.

Relax, I didn't get caught. (pinning the picture over his desk) And you'd do the same. (beat) Now did you guys come over to ask me some questions? Because if you didn't, then I have some studying to do. A tense silence. Les hands Charles the Driver's Ed book. Through the walls, the classical music builds in intensit
All right. How can you identify a blind pedestrian to whom you must yield the right of way?
You're not serious.
By their white cane, or guard dog.

This is a complete waste of time. You know your stuff, Les. You've been a passenger in a car for sixteen years. It's not like you're from Bedrock or something. You've lived and breathed this theory bullshit. The music booms through the walls, building to a crescend
(disturbed by the music) What is that shit?  29.

Tchaikovsky!!! Bookish Natalie sits at her desk studying Driver's Ed manual, taking notes, trying to memorize. As studies, her body responds to the music with great intens And then relaxes when the music becomes quiet... Suddenly from an INTERCOM above her desk, we hear Dean's obnoxious voice.

(voice over) Hey, Naaaatalie! If you were ina car traveling at the speed of fifty- five miles per hour, and you collided with a runaway train, would that create any improvements in your face? Her pencil snaps. A total disruption of concentration. Silence. And now we hear the loudest and most disgusting BURP of all time. And then wails of laughter... And then Dean, again.
